text: Ginkgo biloba is available as an over-the-counter drug and reported to cause haemorrhage when coadministered with other antiplatelet agents.
label: Herb name
Pathology
Drug

text: We set out to study the interactions of G. biloba with cilostazol and clopidogrel.
label: Herb name
Drug
Drug

text: A randomized, open-label, crossover study of 10 healthy male volunteers.
label: Study
Cohort
Pathology
Sex

text: The dosage schedules were 120 mg G. biloba, 240 mg G. biloba, 100 mg cilostazol, 200 mg cilostazol, 75 mg clopidogrel, 150 mg clopidogrel, 120 mg G. biloba+ 100 mg cilostazol and 120 mg G. biloba+ 75 mg clopidogrel.

text: Platelet aggregation, platelet count, bleeding time and clotting time were measured 0 and 6 h after drug administration.
label: Parameter
Parameter
Parameter
Parameter

text: Platelet aggregation was performed using a dual channel aggregometer, by the turbimetric technique using adenosine diphosphate 5 µmol and 10 µmol, and collagen 1 µg ml Platelet inhibition with the combination of G. biloba and clopidogrel or cilostazol was not statistically significant compared with individual doses of drugs, with all the three aggregants.
label: Parameter
Herb name
Drug
Drug

text: There was significant (P< 0.05) potentiation of prolongation of bleeding time with the combination of cilostazol and G. biloba compared with individual doses of both the drugs.
label: Parameter
Drug
Herb name

text: There was no significant change in clotting time and platelet count.
label: Parameter
Parameter

text: Coadministration of G. biloba either with cilostazol or clopidogrel did not enhance antiplatelet activity compared with individual agents.
label: Herb name
Drug
Drug

text: Ginkgo biloba potentiated the bleeding time prolongation effect of cilostazol.
label: Herb name
Parameter
Drug

text: There was no significant correlation between prolongation of bleeding time and inhibition of platelet aggregation.
label: Parameter
Parameter
